skill.name: scikit-survival
skill.description: Comprehensive toolkit for survival analysis and time-to-event modeling in Python using scikit-survival. Use this skill when working with censored survival data, performing time-to-event analysis, fitting Cox models, Random Survival Forests, Gradient Boosting models, or Survival SVMs, evaluating survival predictions with concordance index or Brier score, handling competing risks, or implementing any survival analysis workflow with the scikit-survival library.
skill.summary: Comprehensive toolkit for survival analysis and time-to-event modeling in Python using scikit-surviv...
skill.author: K-Dense Inc.

security_audit.summary: The skill contains documentation and examples only. No data access, network calls, or execution logic were found.

content.value_statement: Survival analysis is complex when data is censored or has competing risks. This skill provides clear workflows and model guidance for scikit-survival.
actual_capabilities: Explain how to prepare survival outcomes with Surv
Guide selection of Cox, ensemble, and SVM survival models
Describe evaluation with C-index, Brier score, and time-dependent AUC
Outline competing risks analysis with cumulative incidence
Provide scikit-learn pipeline and cross-validation patterns
limitations: Does not run code or install packages
Requires user data to be prepared in scikit-survival formats
Does not cover deep learning survival models
No automated dataset download or management

use_cases.title: Evaluate patient survival
use_cases.description: Select Cox or ensemble models and evaluate with Uno C-index and Brier score for censored clinical data.

use_cases.title: Compare model families
use_cases.description: Run a structured comparison of Cox, Random Survival Forest, Gradient Boosting, and SVM approaches.

use_cases.title: Study competing risks
use_cases.description: Learn how to estimate cumulative incidence and interpret competing event probabilities.

prompt_templates.title: Start with basics
prompt_templates.prompt: Explain how to create a survival target with Surv and choose a simple Cox model workflow.

prompt_templates.title: Metric selection
prompt_templates.prompt: Recommend evaluation metrics for high censoring and show how to compute Uno C-index and integrated Brier score.

prompt_templates.title: Model comparison
prompt_templates.prompt: Provide a plan to compare Cox, Random Survival Forest, and Gradient Boosting models with cross-validation.

prompt_templates.title: Competing risks
prompt_templates.prompt: Show how to estimate cumulative incidence functions for two competing events and interpret the curves.

output_examples.input: Help me choose a model and evaluation plan for a censored dataset with 30 percent events.
output: Recommend CoxPH and Random Survival Forest as baselines
Use Uno C-index and integrated Brier score for evaluation
Standardize features if using SVM or penalized Cox

best_practices: Standardize features for SVMs and regularized Cox models
Report multiple metrics including Uno C-index and Brier score
Validate censoring rates and data quality before modeling
anti_patterns: Using Harrell C-index with high censoring
Treating competing events as simple censoring

faq.question: Is this compatible with scikit-survival and scikit-learn?
faq.answer: Yes. The guidance follows scikit-survival APIs and scikit-learn workflows.

faq.question: What are the limits of this skill?
faq.answer: It provides guidance and examples but does not run code or manage datasets.

faq.question: Can I integrate it with existing pipelines?
faq.answer: Yes. Use the pipeline and scorer patterns shown for cross-validation and grid search.

faq.question: Does it access my data or credentials?
faq.answer: No. It contains documentation only and has no data access or network calls.

faq.question: What if my model performs poorly?
faq.answer: Check censoring rates, feature scaling, and compare multiple model families with proper metrics.

faq.question: How does it compare to general ML guidance?
faq.answer: It is specialized for censored time-to-event data and survival-specific metrics.
